subject: Brain activity, AI reveal why people struggle to recognize faces from other racial groups
content: Plus: Gene variant could protect against inherited form of dementia <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #345ba8;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> The Bulletin Brief is a news digest about the University of Toronto, compiled for staff, faculty and librarians. May 23, 2025 // Subscribe to The Bulletin Brief <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> // View this email in your browser <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> Researchers at the University of Toronto Scarborough are using electroencephalography brain monitoring and AI to explore the so-called "other-race-effect" (photo by Don Campbell) Brain activity, AI reveal why people struggle to recognize faces from other racial groups <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> The research results could be harnessed to improve facial recognition software, better diagnose certain mental health disorders and boost accuracy of eyewitness testimony. Driving scientific discovery (photo by Pamela Joe McFarlane/Getty Images) * Gene variant could protect against inherited form of dementia <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> A new study suggests that people who are at risk for rare genetic forms of frontotemporal dementia should consider being tested for a common gene variant that can protect them against the group of disorders. Building inclusive cities and societies Timothy Snyder joined U of Ts Munk School of Global Affairs & Public Policy as a professor and inaugural Chair in Modern European History, supported by the Temerty Endowment for Ukrainian Studies, earlier this year after more than two decades at Yale University (photo by Dmytro Vaga/Babel.ua/Global Images Ukraine via Getty Images) * Timothy Snyders new U of T course explores legacy of authoritarian regimes <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> This winter, world-renowned historian Timothy Snyder's course will challenge first-year University of Toronto students to explore the Nazi and Stalinist regimes to place them in a global historical context and consider their relevance to addressing contemporary challenges. Updates from U of T * National AccessAbility Week May 25 to 31 <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> To learn more about this week and find related resources, please visit the Dates of Recognition, Observance & Celebration webpage. * Guidance on safeguarding your data while travelling <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> U of T Information Security has updated its travel guidance with new tips on protecting data while travelling internationally. Don't miss it! May 23 * OISE dean's salon - Afro-Indigenous intersections: Past and present <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> (Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, Waakebiness Institute for Indigenous Health, Dalla Lana School of Public Health, Ontario Network Environments for Indigenous Health Research, Indigenous Literatures Lab, Indigenous Education Network, and the Centre for Black Studies in Education) May 29 * Italian-Canadian narratives and Indigenous presence in public memory <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> (Department of Italian Studies) May 30 * Making space for Black performance <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> (Centre for Drama, Theatre & Performance Studies) May 31 * UTAA annual meeting and keynote presentation <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> (Alumni) Social spotlight <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;> (video by Kimberly Lyn via @uoftalumni <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> and @uoftlibraries <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;>/Instagram) How do you pack up all your memories of home? Her Suitcase at the Richard Charles Lee Canada-Hong Kong Library inside Robarts Library explores Chinese immigrant womens experiences <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> in Canada since the 1950s. Extended to May <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;> for Asian Heritage Month, its curated by Jessica Cheng and based on U of T alum Vivienne Poys research. If you have any questions, comments or thoughts you'd like to share, you can reach us at bulletin.brief@utoronto.ca <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #007fa3;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: none;>. <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;> <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;> <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;> <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;> Archives <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #ffffff;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: underline;> | Contact Us <mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #ffffff;font-weight: normal;text-decoration: underline;> This edition of the The Bulletin Brief was produced by University of Toronto Communications.
